newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West next-day power rises, back-months steady.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West next-day power rises, back-months steady.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the western U.S. were steady to higher Wednesday, bolstering by forecasts of extended hot weather and higher daily Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) prices, market sources said.
"It's just a little hotter weather that's pushing it up," said one East Coast-based trader. "It's getting a bit hotter in Nevada."

Next-day prices were hoisted amid a BPA reported hike of its posting for 16-hour power blocks for Thursday by 40 cents to $17.90 per megawatt hour (MWh). Values for other BPA daily products were heard flat to up one dollar from Tuesday.
Deferred-month prices were sharply lower in early trading, but trimmed most of their losses toward unchanged from Tuesday's ranges, brokers and traders said.
In today's physical market, California-Oregon Border (COB) prices for firm, peak delivery were quoted at $17.00-$17.90 per MWh, up from Tuesday's $16.00-$17.00 range.
September COB power for firm, peak delivery was assessed at $17.50-$18.25, up from Tuesday's $17.10-$17.90.

October COB, with similar delivery terms, was pegged at $15.75-$16.25, compared with $15.50-$15.90 on Tuesday, and firm, peak COB for the 1996 fourth-quarter was valued at $16.25-$16.75, down from Tuesday's $16.90-$17.25 range.
Further north at the Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) delivery point in Washington, firm, peak electricity prices for next-day delivery were quoted at $15.50-$16.50 per MWh, up from $15.00-$15.50 on Tuesday.
September Mid-C electricity was pegged at $17.25-$17.75, up from Tuesday's $16.50-$17.10. October Mid-C was quoted in the $15.50 area.
Down at the Palo Verde (PV) switchyard close to Phoenix, Ariz., next-day electricity for peak, firm delivery was valued at $22.00-$22.50 per MWh, up from Tuesday's $21.00-$22.00.

September firm, peak PV prices were quoted at $20.70-$21.25, compared with $20.75-$21.25 on Tuesday. October PV electricity, with similar delivery terms, was assessed at $15.75-$16.50, compared with Tuesday's range of $15.90-$16.10.
Fourth-quarter 1996 PV prices were quoted at $16.20-$16.50, down slightly from $16.30-$16.70 on Tuesday. Several deals were heard done at $16.30 and $16.40.

Firmer natural gas prices in the West provided support for PV electricity, traders said. Natgas prices for September delivery to San Juan, N.M., ended today in the high $1.50-range, up eight to nine cents from earlier trading.
Pacific Gas & Electric Co said its 2,160 MW Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in central California resumed full output today after production was reduced for a couple of days because of a nearby wildfire.
